18. Anne Bonny (1700 CE - 1782 CE): an Irish pirate who sailed the Caribbean Sea and was known for her fierce temperament and fearlessness in battle. She began her piracy career at the age of 16.
19. Mary Shelley (1797 CE - 1851 CE): an English novelist who wrote the classic novel Frankenstein at the age of 18.
20. Sacagawea (1788 CE - 1812 CE): a Shoshone woman who served as a guide and interpreter for the Lewis and Clark Expedition in the early 19th century.
21. Sybil Ludington (1761 CE - 1839 CE): an American Revolutionary War heroine who rode her horse through the night to warn American troops of a British attack at the age of 16.
22. Nancy Wake (1912 CE - 2011 CE): a New Zealand-born Australian spy who worked for the French Resistance during World War II and was known as the "White Mouse" for her ability to evade capture.
23. Nzinga of Ndongo and Matamba (1583 CE - 1663 CE): a queen of the Ndongo and Matamba kingdoms in what is now Angola who led her people in a long struggle against Portuguese colonization.
24. Mira Bai (1498 CE - 1547 CE): an Indian princess and poet who wrote devotional poetry in praise of the god Krishna and became known as a spiritual leader in her region.
25. Pocahontas (1596 CE - 1617 CE): a Native American woman who played a key role in early English colonization efforts in Virginia and was known for her friendship with English colonist John Smith.
26. Mary Anning (1799 CE - 1847 CE): an English fossil hunter who made several significant discoveries of prehistoric creatures, including ichthyosaurs and plesiosaurs, at the age of 12.
27. Margaret Bourke-White (1904 CE - 1971 CE): an American photographer who was the first female war correspondent and covered major events such as World War II and the partition of India.
28. Anne Sullivan (1866 CE - 1936 CE): an American teacher who worked with deaf and blind student Helen Keller and helped her learn to communicate, beginning when Anne was 20 years old.
29. Maud Stevens Wagner (1877 CE - 1961 CE): an American circus performer who became the first known female tattoo artist in the United States at the age of 18.
30. Frieda Belinfante (1904 CE - 1995 CE): a Dutch cellist who became involved in the resistance movement during World War II and helped smuggle Jewish children out of the Netherlands.
31. Wilma Rudolph (1940 CE - 1994 CE): an American track and field athlete who overcame polio as a child and went on to win three gold medals in the 1960 Olympic Games at the age of 20.
32. Mariya Oktyabrskaya (1905 CE - 1944 CE): a Soviet tank driver who joined the army after her husband was killed in World War II and became the first female tanker to be awarded the Hero of the Soviet Union medal.
33. Boudica (died 60/61 CE): a queen of the Iceni tribe in Britain who led an uprising against Roman occupation and is remembered as a symbol of British resistance.
